    data-notes: This presentation examines the spread of farming across the Central and Western North Mediterranean (from Italy to Portugal) between 6000 and 5000 BC using quantitative methods. Specifically, it employs the R neonet framework to analyze over 2,500 curated radiocarbon dates from the latest phases of the Mesolithic and the earliest phases of the Neolithic (Huet et al., 2022 and 2024), calculating the isochrones of the farming pioneer front and incorporating palaeoclimate reconstructions (via the R pastclim package). Although the granularity of our modeling does not allow for precise mapping of subregional ecozones (e.g., wetlands), the diffusion model clearly demonstrates that ecological barriers, such as latitudes and mountain ranges, significantly slowed the neolithization process. Furthermore, our framework offers substantial potential for reproducibility and enhances comparisons with previous models (e.g., Binder et al., 2019). The early farmer colonization of Southern Italy, around 6000 BC, aligns with the PPN (Pre-Pottery Neolithic) core model of neolithization, which posits early farming settlements in temperate climates with dry, hot summers ('Csa' in the Köppen Climate Classification). Once early farmers reached the Tyrrhenian Sea, between 5800 and 5600 BC, the process of 'leapfrog' colonization began, marked by Neolithic settlements established along the Mediterranean shore via seafaring, without prior continental continuity. From 5600 to 5000 BC, we observe the resilience of the latest foragers (Late Mesolithic), who became 'cornered' in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula, particularly in regions such as Galicia, Asturias, and Cantabria.

### Methods

Köppen climate classification

::: columns

::: {.column width="40%"}
<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/thomashuet/master/img/app-github.png" style="height: 70px;vertical-align: middle;"/><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim/master/man/figures/logo.png" style="height: 80px;vertical-align: middle;"/>
<small>function [pastclim::koeppen_geiger()](https://github.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim)<br></small>

```{.r}
A <- Thot >= 18 & !B
Af <- A & Pdry >= 60
Am <- A & !Af & Pdry >= 100 - MAP / 25
Aw <- A & !Af & Pdry < 100 - MAP / 25
```

::: notes
- *pastclim* R package to recreate the Koppen Climate classification (KCC) for past periods, currently from 8,000 BC to 5,000 cal BC (expressed here in cal BP)
- KCC based on average temperature and precipitation patterns, dividing them into five main types: tropical, dry, temperate, continental, and polar. Each type is further subdivided based on seasonal precipitation and temperature patterns (30 classes).
- The pastclim KCC current resolution is 30" = 0.5 degrees = c. 50 km. It uses the Beyer *et al.* 2020 dataset.
:::

::: notes
- Late foragers: Drop of the inhabited cold climates from 11k BP to 7k BP. In 9k BP newly occupied occupied Cold, dry summer, cold summer, possibly corresponding to the higher mountain range (Atlas, Alps, Pyrenees, etc.)
- Early Farmers: 11k and 10k 2 main climates, continuous area: Fertile Crescent. Arid climates increases in 9k: arid margins (oasis). 8k and 7k: neolithisation of cold and temperated areas (Bulgaria, Southern Germany, etc.)
- Comparison: LM occupied a larger diversity of ecozones. EF replace HG in cold climate over 4,000 years  
:::

- **7000 BC** Same two main Temperate dry summer climates (`Cs*`) with more `BW*` (`BWh` and `BWk`: Arid desert) climates. First settlements in Creta (`Csa` climate)

<small>ca 10,000-9,500 BC, Near East <span style="color:#FFDC64;">BSk</span> (*Temperate, dry summer, warm summer*), <span style="color:#FFFF00;">Csa</span> (*Temperate, dry summer, hot summer*) and, more rarely, <span style="color:#FF00FF;">Dsa</span> (*Cold, dry summer, hot summer*) climates.</small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide3.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 9,000-7,500 BC, Near East <span style="color:#FF0000;">BWh</span> climate (*Arid, desert, hot*), ie: arid margins. </small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide4.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 8,000-7,500 BC, Near East (South Levant), <span style="color:#F5A500;">BSh</span> (*Arid, steppe, hot*), and <span style="color:#FF9696;">BWk</span> (*Arid, desert, cold*).</small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide5.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 6,500-6,000 BC, Balkans (between North and South), <span style="color:#C8FF50;">Cfa</span> climate (*Temperate, no dry season, hot summer*).</small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide6.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 6,100-6,000 BC, Balkans, <span style="color:#37C8FF;">Dfb</span> (*Cold, no dry season, warm summer*) = Proto-Sesklo Culture.</small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide7.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 6,100-6,000 BC, Northern Balkans and Central Europe, <span style="color:#00FFFF;">Dfa</span> (*Cold, no dry season, hot summer*), outside the studied area.</small>

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/neonet/master/doc/talks/2024-asd/img/Slide8.PNG){width="1000" style="horizontal-align: middle;"}

<small>ca 5,500-5,300 BC, Western Mediterranean, <span style="color:#C8C800;">Csb</span> climate (*Temperate, dry summer, warm summer*)</small>
